title: 111_hr4506
content: The "Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2010" establishes additional permanent offices of bankruptcy judges. The "Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2010" establishes additional permanent offices of bankruptcy judges and amends various districts in the United States Code. The "Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2010" establishes new bankruptcy judgeships and adjusts the number of judges in various districts across the United States. The "Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2010" establishes new bankruptcy judgeships and adjusts the number of judges in various districts across the United States. In the southern district of New York, the number of judges is changed from 2 to 3. In the eastern district of North Carolina, the number of judges is changed from 2 to 3. In the middle district of Pennsylvania, the number of judges is changed from 2 to 3. In the eastern district of Tennessee, the number of judges is changed from 3 to 4. In the western district of Tennessee, the number of judges is changed from 4 to 5. In the eastern district of Virginia, the number of judges is changed from 5 to 6. In the southern district of West Virginia, the number of judges is changed from 1 to 2. Conversion of temporary offices of bankruptcy judges to permanent offices is addressed in Section 3. The temporary offices of bankruptcy judges established by Public Law 109-8 are converted to permanent offices for specific districts. The temporary offices of bankruptcy judges established by Public Law 102-361 are converted to permanent offices for specific districts, including the western district of Tennessee, the eastern district of Virginia, the district of Nevada, the district of Delaware, the district of New Hampshire, and the eastern district of Tennessee. SEC. 4 extends temporary offices of bankruptcy judges in Pennsylvania and North Carolina until a vacancy occurs 5 years after enactment. SEC. 5 addresses PAYGO offset. The text chunk discusses amendments to bankruptcy filing fees and the United States Trustee Fund in title 28 of the United States Code. Filing fees are increased, and adjustments are made to trustee fund percentages. Amendments to bankruptcy filing fees in title 28 of the United States Code include adjustments to miscellaneous fees such as reducing fees from $28.87 to $28.74, $35.00 to $34.77, and $25 to $23.99. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the date of enactment, with a special effective date for amendments in section 5 set at 180 days after enactment.
